content.text: **Gottlob Frege** (1848-1925) revolutionized logic with his Begriffsschrift (1879) — a 'concept-script' that created modern predicate logic. He invented quantifiers (∀, ∃) and showed how to analyze the logical structure of statements with unprecedented precision.

content.definition: The invention of quantified predicate logic, using variables, predicates, and quantifiers to express logical form. This went far beyond Aristotelian syllogistics in expressive power.

content.text: Frege's goal was **logicism**: proving that mathematics (especially arithmetic) could be derived from pure logic. He developed a formal system for deriving mathematical truths from logical axioms alone.
**Bertrand Russell** (1872-1970) discovered a paradox in Frege's system: consider the set of all sets that don't contain themselves. Does it contain itself? Either answer leads to contradiction.

content.title: Russell's Paradox
premises: Let R = the set of all sets that don't contain themselves
Is R ∈ R? (Does R contain itself?)
If yes: R contains itself, so by definition R ∉ R — contradiction!
If no: R doesn't contain itself, so by definition R ∈ R — contradiction!
content.note: This paradox forced logicians to be more careful about set formation.

content.text: Russell and Whitehead's Principia Mathematica (1910-1913) attempted to rescue logicism by adding 'type theory' to prevent self-reference. It became the foundation of 20th-century logic, though the system was enormously complex.

content.question: What did Frege invent that went beyond Aristotelian logic?
content.explanation: Frege invented modern predicate logic with quantifiers (∀ 'for all' and ∃ 'there exists'), variables, and predicates. This vastly exceeded the expressive power of Aristotelian syllogistics.
